thread.title: Subway chicken strips 'contained less than 50% chicken DNA' | Metro News
thread.title_full: Subway chicken strips 'contained less than 50% chicken DNA' | Metro News

author: Jen Mills For Metro.Co.Uk
title: Subway chicken strips 'contained less than 50% chicken DNA' | Metro News
text:
Jen Mills for Metro.co.uk Tuesday 28 Feb 2017 11:25 am Fillets and chicken strips were tested (Picture: Subway) 
Chicken strips sold at Subway had less than 50% chicken DNA, a study has claimed. 
Samples were taken of five oven roasted chicken fillets and five chicken strips. 
When the results came back from sandwiches in Canada, the fillets contained 53.6% chicken on average while the strips had just 42.8%. 
The remainder of the DNA was made up from soy protein, the investigation claimed. 
Tests were carried out by CBC working with DNA researcher Matt Harnden from Trent University. (Picture: Rex) 
They analysed samples from four other fast food chains in Ontario, including McDonald’s and Wendy’s. Carriage horse 'collapses' while pulling tourists through New York 
Most were almost 100% chicken (seasoning and marinating would be expected to bring it down slightly), but the result from Subway was so much of an outlier that researchers bought more chicken to carry out the test again. 
The results the second time confirmed the first, leading one customer CBC interviewed, Irena Valenta, to accuse the chain of ‘misrepresentation’ if less than half of the strip was actually chicken. 
Food scientist Ben Bohrer, from the University of Guelph, told CBC fast food chicken is often ‘restructured’– meaning it’s made from smaller pieces of meat bound together rather than from a single cut of meat. 
Extra ingredients such as chemicals or soy may be added to preserve it for longer or bulk it out so it’s cheaper. 
There is no suggestion the samples tested were unsafe. Subway responded 
Metro.co.uk has contacted Subway for comment and to ask about meat used in chicken sandwiches in the UK. 
The chain previously responded to CBC, questioning the accuracy of the tests as their recipes call for one per cent or less of soy protein in chicken products. 
‘Subway Canada cannot confirm the veracity of the results of the lab testing you had conducted,’ the spokesman said. 
‘However, we are concerned by the alleged findings you cite with respect to the proportion of soy content. 
‘Our chicken strips and oven roasted chicken contain 1% or less of soy protein. 
‘We use this ingredient in these products as a means to help stabilize the texture and moisture. 
‘All of our chicken items are made from 100% white meat chicken which is marinated, oven roasted and grilled. 
‘We tested our chicken products recently for nutritional and quality attributes and found it met our food quality standards. 
‘We will look into this again with our supplier to ensure that the chicken is meeting the high standard we set for all of our menu items and ingredients.’ More
